analyzed: theḥ apadāna  padu mukkhi pa vagga
translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽. The Chapter with Padumuttara
The Elder Biḷāradāyaka’s Birth Story
“Not far from the Himalayas,
there is a mountain named Roma;
At the foot of that mountain,
a monk with developed faculties.
Having caught a cat,
I gave it to the monk;
The Great Hero,
the Self-Existent One, the Unconquered One, rejoiced.
“The cat was given to you by me,
with a serene mind;
In whatever rebirth I was reborn,
the fruit of that was produced.
For ninety-four aeons,
the cat I gave;
I do not know of a bad destination,
this is the fruit of the cat.
The four analytical knowledges, …
… the Buddha’s instruction has been carried out.”🔽Thus the elder Biḷāradāyaka recited these verses.

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā biḷālidāyako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.🔽Biḷālidāyakattherassāpadānaṁ pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā biḷālidāyakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati 🔽biḷālidāyaka therassa apadānam pañcama
translated: The Elder Biḷāradāyaka’s Birth Story, the fifth.
